I second toterly's recommendations. I also stayed at the Rendez-Vous, randomly, and loved it. In addition to his/her recommendations, I suggest Human Club on a Saturday night. The Pride Cafe in both Palermo Soho and San Telmo are excellent at all hours, but particularly for their American breakfasts which can be hard to find. Don't forget to eat milanesa and choripan at some point, too. A day trip on the Buquebus hydrofoil to Colonias, Uruguay is a nice change of pace from super urban Buenos Aires. Beaches are harder to come by...either Punta del Este or Mar del Plata. With two weeks you might even consider a brief trip down to El Calafate for glacier tours. The scenery is stunning. Enjoy and congratulations!

Life is Good. Part One
Life is good. We can celebrate a half century of environmental achievements that brought us the defeat of the smoggy 70', all sorts of laws and environmental protections and standards and checks and lots of clear blue skies and clean water that makes NOW, the best time in history to be alive. We are living longer now than at any time in history despite grave concerns for access to quality health care and it sure beats choking in a smoke filled tent and fighting for the water hole every day.
Being an environmentalist means that you can be a Nature lover, steward of the environment, ecologist, conservationist and naturalist on your own terms, just like anything else in this glorious life of ours. I preserve, protect and respect Nature. Respect for Nature means admitting the powers of the cosmos are still a great mystery, that Nature is not delicate, or fragile or weak, but rather power personified and we are to it as water in the tank, is to a gold fish. We can't change the water, “a” God does that. While our effects may be temporary, in the long term our effects on the planet Earth are like passing gas in a septic tank.

Nature will have its way. No amount of politicizing science or complaining about it will change the planet one iota. Science, while imperfect, does its best to observe and has developed some checks - not perfect - on reality. Those who have sour attitudes or have chosen to grab at the bait of the various manufactured -gates are happy with their wishful thinking - misery loves company - but in the end none of this posturing is going to change the facts.

Hansen did a pretty good job of predicting all this in 1981. He was a good enough messenger to be a target for disingenuous tactics and hate mongering. Gore collected a lot of good science and did a pretty good job of publicizing it, so he too is now a target. The "hockey stick" is quite accurate, and providing pretty resilient, so now it too is a target of disinformation.

But none of this matters at all. Reality will keep on turning up the amplifier until either we are all gone or we begin to listen and be proactive. My guess is it will be too late, but a good few lucky and wealthy types will escape. Sad that others will pay for our self-indulgence.

The Germans are doing better but their industrial leaders complain about the $8 Billion dollars of economic activity is going to expensive renewables and other green programs. Bill Gates knows that it wasn't manufacturing volume that lead to lower computer costs is was geometric reduction in the size of transisters that lead to price declines. With utilitity scale power, you see the exact opposite, As wind turbines get bigger they get more power from a given acreage. What Bill Gates was saying is what Roger Pielke Sr (also a member of the Breakthrough Institute) has been saying for some years now, you won't push acceptance of renewable by making people poorer. You'll get there by making renewable power cheaper than todays fossile fuels. Unfortunately we are no where close to that point.

If you want klutzy, unimaginative solutions to energy problems, you can follow the Microsoft methodology of spending huge amounts of money to produce mediocre products. Windows Vista and Internet Explorer are classic examples of why large spending does not guarantee good products or results.

JD

Our paper was written with the goal of understanding how people perceive (or misperceive) energy use in their day-to-day activities. To investigate public perceptions of energy, we compare people’s responses to questions about specific activities and behaviors with the best available data about actual energy use for those behaviors.

Several people commented on the comparison of central air conditioning with an individual room air conditioner. Our survey results suggest that people underestimate the relative difference between energy used by central AC and energy used by room AC in one hour. When a decision about air conditioning is to be made, we believe people should be informed about the actual energy use for the specific scenario being considered. In some homes and locations, using an individual room air conditioner makes more sense than central air conditioning, while in other cases the reverse is true.

There were many comments about bicycling compared with driving an energy efficient car. Of course riding a bicycle or walking uses less energy than driving any powered vehicle. It is great that people consider curtailing their energy use by turning off the lights and bicycling to work. Our point regarding curtailment and efficiency was a general one; we did not intended to imply that all efficiency-related behaviors are superior to all curtailment behaviors. However, curtailing behaviors may be difficult to maintain over a long period of time to actually realize a decrease energy use. Thus, we feel it is important for people to understand the impact of both curtailment AND increasing efficiency through new technologies. We are not advocating any particular behavior, but rather advocating better understanding of the actual energy used by various devices and technologies.

There were several comments related to the life-cycle energy of appliances, including extraction of raw materials, manufacturing, use and disposal, not just the use phase. We agree that life-cycle issues are very important, but we did not assess perceptions of life-cycle costs in this survey. Both the "perceived" energy use and the "actual" energy use would be much harder to assess if the full life cycle were considered.

Some people questioned whether the energy saved by reducing the water temperature in washing machines is actually greater than the energy saved by drying clothes on the line. Our survey question described a specific scenario, namely changing washer temperature settings from “hot wash, warm rinse” to “warm wash, cold rinse”. We used published values for the average amount of water used and estimated temperatures of hot, warm, and cold water to calculate energy saved of around 4 kwh. A typical dryer with one load of laundry uses around 3.4 kwh. One reason for the difference is that it takes a lot of energy to heat a given quantity of water, more than heating air to evaporate water from clothing. (We caution that some energy figures for washers may not include the energy used to heat the water, which is most of the energy used in washing clothes.) Of course, we agree with the many comments suggesting that it is best to do both – reducing washing machine temperatures AND line drying our clothes.

A few comments pointed out that an improvement in energy efficiency in an appliance or a vehicle can result in the appliance being used more, or the vehicle being driven more. This “rebound” effect, as it is called, is indeed a potential problem that can erode some of the benefit of a higher efficiency. The severity of the rebound effect can vary, depending on the specific circumstances of each situation. However, this does not mean that higher efficiencies are to be avoided -- rather it is an indication that we should be aware of this potential problem and take steps such as providing education and incentives to reduce the effect.

Finally, a few comments asked for suggestions on what to do to save energy. We did not include such a list in our paper because our purpose was focused on assessing people’s understanding of energy use. However, we can refer readers to an article by Thomas Dietz and others entitled “Household Action Can Provide a Behavioral Wedge to Rapidly Reduce U.S. Carbon Emissions,” available online at: behavioralwedge.msu.edu. We agree with the many comments noting that savings add up when small energy-saving behaviors are performed consistently and by many people, but we also suggest that savings might accumulate more quickly if people (ourselves included) had a better understanding of the full spectrum of possibilities.

We thank readers for their comments and hope this posting reduces any misunderstandings or confusion about our article.

Shahzeen Attari, Michael DeKay, Cliff Davidson, Wandi Bruine de Bruin
